abstract.p: Controversial Web site Napster, which has sponsored free concerts in past, plans to charge $4 admission for Get Up Kids concert at Rutgers University; photo (S)

block.p: What's up with the emo-alternative band The Get Up Kids (below), charging admission to their Napster-sponsored concert at Rutgers?

In the past, Napster, the controversial song-sharing Web site, has sponsored free concerts for bands like Limp Bizkit who are sympathetic to their cause. Many high-profile musical artists, however, object to the company, claiming lost royalties and infringed copyrights because of Napster's free downloading service.
What's up with the emo-alternative band The Get Up Kids (below), charging admission to their Napster-sponsored concert at Rutgers?

In the past, Napster, the controversial song-sharing Web site, has sponsored free concerts for bands like Limp Bizkit who are sympathetic to their cause. Many high-profile musical artists, however, object to the company, claiming lost royalties and infringed copyrights because of Napster's free downloading service.

It seems logical, though, that Napster would continue its power-to-the-people philosophy to live performance. This concert featuring the Kids' combination of overly sensitive lyrics and blaring rock might just end up as bootleg tapes for those true Napster fans who would like to forgo the $4 admission. The show takes place at 8 p.m. Oct. 4, at the New Brunswick campus, Trayes Hall.
